message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest temporal arteritis, which can result in vision loss if not treated. Therefore, the best initial step in management is to start treatment with methylprednisolone. 100% oxygen is not indicated in this case, and CT head is not the best initial step. Ibuprofen and acetaminophen may provide pain relief but not treat the underlying condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location, severity, and the patient's age suggest that the most likely diagnosis is temporal arteritis. Methylprednisolone is used to treat temporal arteritis and is the best initial step in management. CT head is not necessary as the symptoms do not suggest any head injury or intracranial pathology. 100% oxygen and ibuprofen and acetaminophen are not appropriate treatments for temporal arteritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and tenderness to palpation over the right temporal region are suggestive of temporal arteritis. The best initial step in management is to start the patient on high-dose methylprednisolone to prevent permanent vision loss. CT head would not be the best initial step in this case as it is unlikely to show any abnormalities in temporal arteritis. Oxygen, ibuprofen, and acetaminophen are not appropriate initial management steps for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest temporal arteritis, which can lead to vision loss if left untreated. The best initial step in management is to start treatment with high-dose corticosteroids like methylprednisolone to prevent irreversible vision loss. 100% oxygen may be helpful in some types of headache, but it is not likely to be effective in this case. CT head may rule out other causes of headache, but it is not the best initial step in management. Ibuprofen and acetaminophen may help with pain relief, but they do not address the underlying inflammation in temporal arteritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of temporal arteritis, which is a medical emergency. The best initial step in management is to start treatment with high-dose steroids such as methylprednisolone, which can prevent permanent vision loss. CT head or 100% oxygen are not appropriate treatments for this condition, and ibuprofen and acetaminophen are not strong enough to treat the headache associated with temporal arteritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest giant cell arteritis, which can cause vision changes and tenderness over the temporal region. A CT scan will not necessarily show findings specific to giant cell arteritis, and 100% oxygen or ibuprofen/acetaminophen will not treat the underlying condition. Methylprednisolone can help reduce the inflammation associated with giant cell arteritis, and is therefore the best initial step in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The localized headache and blurry vision suggest temporal arteritis, which is a medical emergency. The best initial step in management is to start methylprednisolone to reduce inflammation and prevent vision loss. CT head or 100% oxygen will not help with the underlying issue, and ibuprofen and acetaminophen are not effective for temporal arteritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with symptoms of temporal arteritis and the best initial step in management would be to start treatment with high-dose glucocorticoids, such as Methylprednisolone, to reduce inflammation and prevent further damage. CT head is not necessary for diagnosis of temporal arteritis and 100% oxygen is not indicated in this case. Ibuprofen and acetaminophen may not provide adequate relief for the severe headache associated with temporal arteritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest temporal arteritis, which is a medical emergency that can lead to blindness if not treated immediately. A CT head would not be helpful in diagnosing this condition. 100% oxygen and ibuprofen/acetaminophen would not be effective treatment for temporal arteritis. Methylprednisolone is the initial step in management for suspected temporal arteritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest Giant cell arteritis, which can cause blindness if left untreated. The best initial step in management is to treat with high-dose corticosteroids such as methylprednisolone before performing further imaging or diagnostic testing. 100% oxygen is not indicated in this situation. CT head may not be the most appropriate initial diagnostic test in this case. Ibuprofen and acetaminophen may help with pain, but will not treat the underlying condition.
